submission_metadata.country: Norway & Rwanda as co-chairs of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution

citation: Norway and Rwanda submit this written input as co-chairs of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution.
The options seek to contribute to the strategic goals of the HAC to meet our common ambition to end plastic pollution by 2040.
Proposed Objective: To end plastic pollution and protect the environment and human health from plastic pollution.

The title of the UNEA resolution 5/14, End Plastic Pollution: Towards an International Legally-binding Instrument, has already settled ending plastic pollution as the ultimate goal of the Treaty (in the public sphere).
end_plastic_pollution.reasoning: The document explicitly and repeatedly mentions the goal of ending plastic pollution, both in the name of the submitting coalition and as a proposed primary objective for the international instrument. A specific timeframe is provided, stating the ambition is 'to end plastic pollution by 2040.'

other_objectives.value: Achieve a circular economy for plastics, promote transparency through harmonized standards, ensure a just transition for workers, create national accountability mechanisms, and establish a financial mechanism to support implementation.
citation: ...include specific, binding provisions that can be translated into national-level accountability mechanisms.
...achieve a circular economy for plastics, and ensure that all remaining plastic can be collected, sorted, and recycled in an environmentally sound manner.
The treaty must promote transparency across the plastics value chain, from production to waste, by establishing harmonized monitoring and reporting standards.
Furthermore, it should ensure a just transition for all stakeholders involved, particularly waste pickers and other workers in the informal waste sector.
A dedicated financial mechanism must be established to support the implementation of the treaty, especially in low- and middle-income countries.
other_objectives.reasoning: The document outlines several distinct policy objectives that are not covered by the excluded categories. These include economic and structural goals (achieving a circular economy), governance and transparency goals (national accountability, harmonized monitoring), social equity goals (a just transition for workers), and financial support goals (a dedicated financial mechanism). These are specific aims related to the implementation, fairness, and funding of the treaty, rather than the core environmental and health outcomes themselves.
